review.title: The Rationale behind the Concept of Goal
review.abstract: The paper proposes a fresh look at the concept of goal and advances that motivational attitudes like desire, goal and intention are just facets of the broader notion of (acceptable) outcome. We propose to encode the preferences of an agent as sequences of "alternative acceptable outcomes". We then study how the agent's beliefs and norms can be used to filter the mental attitudes out of the sequences of alternative acceptable outcomes. Finally, we formalise such intuitions in a novel Modal Defeasible Logic and we prove that the resulting formalisation is computationally feasible.

sections.heading: 2 The intuition underneath the framework
sections.text: When a cognitive agent thinks about what her results are in a given situation, she selects a set of preferred results under a larger framework where each specific outcome has different alternatives. It is natural to evaluate such alternatives in a preferred order, from the preferred choice to the least objective place she considers acceptable. Consider, for example, the following scenario she visits on a Saturday afternoon. She has three alternatives: (i) she can visit John; (ii) she can visit her parents, who live near John's home; or (ii) she can watch a movie at home. The alternative she likes most is to visit John while watching a movie, which is the least preferred. If John is not at home, there is no point for him. In this case, paying a visit to her parents becomes the "next best" option.

Approaches like the BOID (Belief, Obligation, Intention, Desire) architecture [Broersen et al., 2002] and Governatori and Rotolo [2008]’s system improve previous frameworks, for instance, by structurally solving conflicts between beliefs and intentions (the former being always stronger than any conflicting intention), while mental attitudes and obligations are just meant to define which kinds of agent (social, realistic, selfish, and so on) are admissible.

On the other hand, if the agent does not respect the norms governing the environment she acts in, then she may incur sanctions from other agents [Bratman, 1987]. The BDI approach is based on the following assumptions about the motivational and deliberative components. The agent typically defines a priori her desires and intentions, and only after this is done the system verifies their mutual consistency by using additional axioms. Such entities are therefore not interrelated with one another since “the notion of intention [. . . ] has equal status with the notions of belief and desire, and cannot be reduced to these concepts” [Rao and Georgeff, 1991]. Moreover, the agent may consequently have intentions which are contradictory with her beliefs and this may be verified only a posteriori. Therefore, one of the main conceptual deficiencies of the BDI paradigm (and generally of almost all classical approaches to model rational agents) is that the deliberation process is bound to these mental attitudes which are independent and fixed a priori. Here, with the term independent, we mean that none of them is fully definable in terms of the others. Their central thesis, supported by Prakken [2006], is that only by adopting a credulous interpretation is it possible to have conflicting goals. However, we believe that a credulous interpretation is not suitable if an agent has to deliberate what her primary goals are in a given situation. We opted to have a sceptical interpretation of the concepts we call goals, intentions, and social intentions, while we adopt a credulous interpretation for desires. Moreover, they do not take into account the distinction between goals and related motivational attitudes (as in [van Riemsdijk et al., 2008, Dastani et al., 2011, 2006]). The characteristic property of intentions in these logics is that an agent may not drop intentions for arbitrary reasons, which means that intentions have a certain persistence. As such, their analysis results orthogonal to ours. Vasconcelos et al. [2009] propose mechanisms for the detection and resolution of normative conflicts.

Again, our choice of Defeasible Logic allows to drastically reduce the number of rules involved in the process of creating, for example, a business process thanks to its exception handling mechanism. This is peculiarly interesting when dealing with the problem of visualising such rules. When dealing with a system with thousands of rules, understanding what they represent or what a group of rules stand for, may be a serious challenge. On the contrary, the model presented by Olivieri et al. metadata.abstractText: The paper proposes a fresh look at the concept of goal and advances that motivational attitudes like desire, goal and intention are just facets of the broader notion of (acceptable) outcome. We propose to encode the preferences of an agent as sequences of “alternative acceptable outcomes”. We then study how the agent’s beliefs and norms can be used to filter the mental attitudes out of the sequences of alternative acceptable outcomes. Finally, we formalise such intuitions in a novel Modal Defeasible Logic and we prove that the resulting formalisation is computationally feasible.
